009package imagingbook.common.filter.generic;
010
011import ij.process.ImageProcessor;
012import imagingbook.common.filter.examples.ExampleFilter3x3Scalar;
013import imagingbook.common.filter.examples.ExampleFilter3x3Vector;
014import imagingbook.common.filter.examples.FilterProgressExample;
015import imagingbook.common.ij.IjProgressBarMonitor;
016import imagingbook.common.image.GridIndexer2D;
017import imagingbook.common.image.OutOfBoundsStrategy;
018import imagingbook.common.image.PixelPack;
019import imagingbook.common.image.PixelPack.PixelSlice;
020import imagingbook.common.util.progress.ProgressMonitor;
021import imagingbook.common.util.progress.ProgressReporter;
022
023/**
024 * <p>
025 * This is the (abstract) root class of the generic filter hierarchy. Generic filters are designed to work with all
026 * types of ImageJ images, i.e., sub-classes of {@link ImageProcessor}. Filters implemented with this framework use a
027 * set of unified image data structures, all based on {@code float} values (see {@link PixelPack} and
028 * {@link PixelSlice}). Input images are transparently copied from and back to these float data, thus authors of new
029 * filters do not need to concern themselves with the original pixel data types. Behind the scenes, classes
030 * {@link GridIndexer2D} and {@link OutOfBoundsStrategy} are relevant for pixel indexing and out-of-boundary coordinates
031 * handling.
032 * </p>
033 * <p>
034 * Generic filters support multiple passes, the associated control structures are implemented by this class
035 * {@link GenericFilter}. Most filters only require a single pass. If more passes are required, the concrete (terminal)
036 * filter class should override the method {@code passesRequired()} to return the required number, which may change
037 * dynamically during the execution of the filter (e.g., to reach convergence of some sort). Sub-classes provide
038 * definitions for scalar filters, i.e., filters that operate independently on the different components of color images
039 * (e.g., see {@link GenericFilterScalar}), as opposed to vector vector filters that deal with color datea as vectors
040 * (e.g., see {@link GenericFilterVector}). In addition, both types provide sub-classes for X/Y-separable versions (see
041 * {@link GenericFilterScalarSeparable} and {@link GenericFilterVectorSeparable}).
042 * </p>
043 * <p>
044 * In the simplest (though frequent) case a concrete filter class only needs to implement a single method to specify the
045 * work to be done for calculating the value of a single image pixel (e.g., see
046 * {@link GenericFilterVector#doPixel(PixelPack, int, int)} and
047 * {@link GenericFilterScalar#doPixel(PixelSlice, int, int)}. See {@link ExampleFilter3x3Scalar} and
048 * {@link ExampleFilter3x3Vector} for examples.
049 * </p>
050 * <p>
051 * To <strong>apply</strong> as filter to a given image, the key method is {@link #applyTo(ImageProcessor)} (or
052 * {@link #applyTo(PixelPack)} if the pixel data are already available as a {@link PixelPack}). All filters operate
053 * destructively, i.e., by modifying the supplied image.
054 * </p>
055 * <p>
056 * {@link GenericFilter}s support asynchronous <strong>progress reporting</strong> based on the {@link ProgressMonitor}
057 * framework. Here is a usage example (from one of the sample plugins):</p>
058 * <pre>
059 * ImageProcessor ip = ... // any image
060 * ...
061 * GenericFilter filter = new TschumperleDericheFilter();
062 * try (ProgressMonitor m = new ProgressBarMonitor(filter)) {
063 *     filter.applyTo(ip);
064 * }</pre>
065 * <p>
066 * During execution of the filter, the {@link IjProgressBarMonitor} instance queries the filter periodically (in a
067 * separate thread) for its progress status and updates ImageJ's progress bar.
068 * </p>
069 *
070 * @author WB
071 * @version 2012/01/12
072 */
073public abstract class GenericFilter implements ProgressReporter {
074        
075        private class AbortFilterException extends RuntimeException {
076                private static final long serialVersionUID = 1L;
077        }
078        
079        private PixelPack source = null;
080        private PixelPack target = null;
081        private int pass = -1;
082        
083        public GenericFilter() {
084        }
085        
086        // --------------------------------------------------------------------------------
087
088        /**
089         * Returns the current filter pass number, starting with 0.
090         * @return the filter pass number
091         */
092        protected int getPass() {
093                return pass;
094        }
095        
096        /**
097         * Returns the width of the currently processed image.
098         * @return the width of the image
099         */
100        protected int getWidth() {
101                if (source == null) {
102                        throw new IllegalStateException("width is unknown unless filter is invoked");
103                }
104                return source.getWidth();
105        }
106        
107        /**
108         * Returns the height of the currently processed image.
109         * @return the height of the image
110         */
111        protected int getHeight() {
112                if (source == null) {
113                        throw new IllegalStateException("height is unknown unless filter is invoked");
114                }
115                return source.getHeight();
116        }
117        
118        /**
119         * Returns the depth (number of components) of the currently processed image.
120         * @return the depth of the image
121         */
122        protected int getDepth() {
123                if (source == null) {
124                        throw new IllegalStateException("depth is unknown unless filter is invoked");
125                }
126                return source.getDepth();
127        }
128        
129        // -----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
130        
131        /**
132         * Applies this filter to the given {@link PixelPack} instance, which is modified.
133         * @param source the image to be filtered
134         */
135        public void applyTo(PixelPack source) {
136                this.source = source;
137                this.target = new PixelPack(source);    // empty copy of same dimensions as source
138                runFilter(source, target);
139        }
140        
141        private void runFilter(PixelPack source, PixelPack target) {    // do we always want to copy back??
142                initFilter(source, target);
143                pass = 0;
144                try {
145                        while (pass < passesRequired()) {       // TODO: check return value of passesRequired()!
146                                //IJ.log("****** starting pass " + pass);
147                                initPass(source, target);
148                                runPass(source, target);
149                                target.copyTo(this.source); // copy target back to sources
150                                pass++;
151                        }
152                } catch (AbortFilterException e) {};
153                // the filter's result is to be found in 'source'
154                closeFilter();
155                this.source = null;
156                this.target = null;
157        }
158        
159        // -----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
160        
161        /**
162         * Applies this filter to the given {@link ImageProcessor}, which is modified.
163         * {@link PixelPack#DefaultOutOfBoundsStrategy} is used to handle out-of-bounds coordinates.
164         * @param ip the image to be filtered
165         */
166        public void applyTo(ImageProcessor ip) {
167                applyTo(ip, PixelPack.DefaultOutOfBoundsStrategy);
168        }
169        
170        /**
171         * Applies this filter to the given {@link ImageProcessor}, which is modified;
172         * the specified {@link OutOfBoundsStrategy} is used to handle out-of-bounds coordinates.
173         * @param ip the image to be filtered
174         * @param obs the out-of-bounds strategy to be used
175         */
176        public void applyTo(ImageProcessor ip, OutOfBoundsStrategy obs) {
177                PixelPack pp = new PixelPack(ip, 1.0, obs);
178                applyTo(pp);
179                pp.copyToImageProcessor(ip);    // copy data back to ip
180        }
181        
182        // -----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
183        
184        // called once before the filter operations starts.
185        // 
186        // that depend on the image size
187        /**
188         * This method is called once at the start of the filter execution.
189         * It does nothing by default.
190         * Concrete filter classes should override this method, 
191         * e.g., for setting up temporary data structures.
192         * 
193         * @param source the image source data
194         * @param target the image target data
195         */
196        protected void initFilter(PixelPack source, PixelPack target) {
197                // does nothing by default
198        }
199        
200        /**
201         * This method is called once at the start of each filter pass.
202         * It does nothing by default.
203         * Concrete filter classes should override this method if needed.
204         * @param source the image source data
205         * @param target the image target data
206         */
207        protected void initPass(PixelPack source, PixelPack target) {
208                // does nothing by default
209        }
210        
211        // concrete sub-classes should override to purge 
212        // specific data structures if needed
213        /**
214         * This method is called once when the filter terminates.
215         * It does nothing by default.
216         * Concrete filter classes should override this method if needed.
217         */
218        protected void closeFilter() {
219        }
220        
221        // limits the necessary number of passes, which may not be known at initialization.
222        // multi-pass filters must override this method.
223        /**
224         * Returns the necessary number of passes, which may change during execution 
225         * of the filter. The value 1 is returned by default.
226         * Multi-pass filters must override this method.
227         * The filter terminates as soon as the requested number of passes is reached.
228         * This this method can be used to terminate filter execution once some desired
229         * state has been reached (e.g., convergence).
230         * See also {@link #getPass()}.
231         * 
232         * @return the required number of filter passes
233         */
234        protected int passesRequired() {
235                return 1;       // do exactly 1 pass
236        }
237        
238        /**
239         * This method can be called to abort the filter execution prematurely,
240         * e.g. for debugging.
241         */
242        protected final void abort() {
243                throw new AbortFilterException();
244        }
245
246        /**
247         * This method performs one pass of the filter, it must be implemented by a sub-class.
248         * There is usually no need for a custom filter class to override this method.
249         * 
250         * @param source the image source data
251         * @param target the image target data
252         */
253        protected abstract void runPass(PixelPack source, PixelPack target);
254        
255        // progress reporting ----------------------------------------------------------------
256
257        @Override
258        public final double getProgress() {
259                double fp = reportProgress();
260                return this.reportProgress(fp);
261        }
262        
263        // 
264        /**
265         * This method is called asynchonously and may be overridden by the terminal filter class 
266         * if it does extensive work that should be monitored. 
267         * In this case the method must return a value between 0 and 1, reflecting the degree of completion
268         * (only of the final class's subtask) at the time of invocation.
269         * Normally this is not necessary, since the intermediate classes
270         * return their own progress state (for the less granular tasks) anyways.
271         * The default implementations returns 0 (progress).
272         * See {@link FilterProgressExample} for an example.
273         * @return the degree of completion (0,...,1)
274         */
275        protected double reportProgress() {
276                return 0;
277        }
278        
279        /** This method is used for internal progress reporting through the class hierarchy. It should
280         * not be overridden or modified.
281         * 
282         * @param subProgress the current progress reported by the immediate sub-task (0,...,1)
283         * @return the cumulative progress (0,...,1)
284         */
285        protected double reportProgress(double subProgress) {
286                int pass = Math.max(getPass(), 0);      // getPass() returns -1 if loop is not started 
287                double localProgress = (pass + subProgress) / passesRequired();
288                return localProgress; // this is the final value returned to the monitor
289        }
290}
